Get started predicting genetic variances

Source: vignettes/predictCrossVars.Rmd
predictCrossVars.Rmd
library(predCrossVar)

Quick simulation of input data

Use AlphaSimR to create quick simulation data to demonstrate the predCrossVar package.

library(tidyverse); library(magrittr);
#> ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ──
#> ✓ ggplot2 3.3.2     ✓ purrr   0.3.4
#> ✓ tibble  3.0.4     ✓ dplyr   1.0.2
#> ✓ tidyr   1.1.2     ✓ stringr 1.4.0
#> ✓ readr   1.4.0     ✓ forcats 0.5.0
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'magrittr'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':
#> 
#>     set_names
#> The following object is masked from 'package:tidyr':
#> 
#>     extract
library(AlphaSimR)
#> Loading required package: R6
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'AlphaSimR'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':
#> 
#>     mutate
founderPop = quickHaplo(nInd=100, nChr=2, segSites=50)
baseSP<-SimParam$new(founderPop)
baseSP$addTraitAD(nQtlPerChr = 10, 
                  mean =10, 
                  var = 50,
                  varD = 20)
pop <- newPop(founderPop,simParam = baseSP) # initial generation
pop %<>% setPheno(simParam = baseSP)
# centimorgan scale map as a named vector
## will be converted to recomb. freq. matrix in tutorial
genmap<-getQtlMap(trait = 1,simParam = baseSP)
m<-genmap$pos; 
names(m)<-paste0(genmap$chr,"_",genmap$site)
genmap<-m; rm(m)
haplos<-pullQtlHaplo(pop,trait = 1,simParam = baseSP)
# for now, it seems the critical internal functions `predOneCrossVarA()` and `predOneCrossVarAD()` 
# require haplotypes for the same individual to be distinguished by "_HapA" and "_HapB"
# will fix in a future version
rownames(haplos) %<>% 
  gsub("_1","_HapA",.) %>% 
  gsub("_2","_HapB",.)
# column IDs for the loci should match in order and ID between all files
colnames(haplos)<-names(genmap)

# effects
addEffects<-baseSP$traits[[1]]@addEff
domEffects<-baseSP$traits[[1]]@domEff
names(addEffects)<-names(domEffects)<-colnames(haplos)

Core functions

At this early development stage, package is unforgiving. There are not many arguments with defaults. Input formats are pretty specific, but well defined.

The package helps automate prediction for both simple (one trait, one cross) and complex (multi-trait, many crosses) scenarios.

predOneCrossVarA(): predict one cross, one variance (or covariance), additive-only model predCrossVarsA(): predict multiple crosses (potentially in parallel/multicore), one variance (or covariance), additive-only model runMtCrossVarPredsA(): wraps around predCrossVarsA(). Predicts the variances predict the variances and covariances for a set of crosses in terms of BVs (breeding values), i.e. additive-only model.

Equivalent functions for an additive-plus-dominance models are: predOneCrossVarAD() –> predCrossVarsAD() –> runMtCrossVarPredsAD(). I didn’t make a function to do only dominance…

There are also functions for the much less computationally challenging prediction of cross means.

The multi-trait, multi-family function, runMtCrossVarPredsA() should be suitable for the univariate, unifamily prediction but users might find the list-of-matrices input format requirement unnecessary.

Predict genetic variances - one cross, one trait

To predict cross variance, 3 types of input are required:

  1. Phased Parental Haplotypes
  2. Genetic Map (or pairwise-recombination frequencies)
  3. Marker Effects

Genetic map

The usual starting place for recombination frequency is a centimorgan-scale genetic map.

# utility function to compute matrix of pairwise recombination frequencies. 
recombFreqMat<-genmap2recombfreq(genmap,nChr = 2)

In practice, these matrices get big as they have dimension \(N_{snp} \times N_{snp}\). It is recommended to precompute and store the recombFreqMat.

In predicting genetic variance in the \(F_1\) cross, the recombFreqMat the matrix \(1-2*recombFreqMat\) is computed. To avoid having to do that separately for each family being predicted, I designed the prediction functions to require \(1-2*recombFreqMat\) as input, to save a great deal of computation. Therefore pre-compute it and store that on disk. Probably this can be improved on!

recombFreqMat<-1-(2*recombFreqMat)
recombFreqMat[1:5,1:5]
#>            1_6       1_7      1_11      1_13      1_18
#> 1_6  1.0000000 0.9600054 0.8153958 0.7514773 0.6127514
#> 1_7  0.9600054 1.0000000 0.8493658 0.7827844 0.6382791
#> 1_11 0.8153958 0.8493658 1.0000000 0.9216104 0.7514773
#> 1_13 0.7514773 0.7827844 0.9216104 1.0000000 0.8153958
#> 1_18 0.6127514 0.6382791 0.7514773 0.8153958 1.0000000

Phased parental haplotypes

The example dataset haplos contains 2 chrom. with 10 loci each (columns) for 100 individuals (200 rows).

dim(haplos)
#> [1] 200  20
haplos[1:5,1:5]
#>        1_6 1_7 1_11 1_13 1_18
#> 1_HapA   1   1    0    0    1
#> 1_HapB   1   1    0    1    1
#> 2_HapA   0   0    1    0    1
#> 2_HapB   0   0    0    0    0
#> 3_HapA   0   1    0    0    0

Marker effects

For an additive-only model, the argument to runMtCrossVarPredsA() AlleleSubEffectList

List of ALLELE SUBSTITUTION EFFECT matrices, one matrix per trait, Each element of the list is named with a string identifying the trait and the colnames of each matrix are labeled with snpIDs. Some (most?) users will have marker effects estimated with REML or only want to use the posterior mean marker effects from a Bayesian marker-regression. That is, some users will only For these (most) users, the argument predType=="VPM" should be used and each matrix of the AlleleSubEffectList will have only one row. Otherwise each matrix has nrow((nIter-burnIn)/thin) and ncol(length(snpIDs)). If only one trait is analyzed, the list AlleleSubEffectList can have just one named-element.
